title: Example Workflow
text: use specification illustrative purposes . specification contains following four modules/equations: first two equations simply accounting identities. third equation models imports function final consumption expenditure households gross capital formation. fourth equation models carbon emissions combustion activities, includes energy industries, manufacturing construction, transport, combustion activities sectors.regressors number heating degree days, harmonised index consumer prices energy, total gross value added.
code: specification <- dplyr::tibble(     type = c(       "d",       "d",       "n",       "n"     ),     dependent = c(       "StatDiscrep",       "TOTS",       "Import",       "EmiCO2Combustion"     ),     independent = c(       "TOTS - FinConsExpHH - FinConsExpGov - GCapitalForm - Export",       "GValueAdd + Import",       "FinConsExpHH + GCapitalForm",       "HDD + HICP_Energy + GValueAdd"     )   ) print(specification) #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>   type  dependent        independent                                             #>   <chr> <chr>            <chr>                                                   #> 1 d     StatDiscrep      TOTS - FinConsExpHH - FinConsExpGov - GCapitalForm - E… #> 2 d     TOTS             GValueAdd + Import                                      #> 3 n     Import           FinConsExpHH + GCapitalForm                             #> 4 n     EmiCO2Combustion HDD + HICP_Energy + GValueAdd

Data can principle downloaded eurostat edgar can also loaded locally saved manually user using save_to_disk argument run_model() previous model run. argument primary_source can take either value "download" "local", governs whether download local input takes precedence eurostat edgar variables. gives rise following combinations obtaining data: variables dictionary$database == "local" always searched among local files inputdata_directory error raised found argument primary_source == "download" first downloads variables (potentially updating values) searches local directory variables obtained way (e.g. problems download) argument primary_source == "local" first searches local directory downloads variables found locally , use variables can principle obtained either Eurostat EDGAR use local file example-workflow-data.rds save time compiling vignette. avoid downloading variables , specify primary_source == "local" provide inputdata_directory path local directory calling run_model().
code: vars <- c("StatDiscrep", "TOTS", "Import", "EmiCO2Combustion", "FinConsExpHH",           "FinConsExpGov", "GCapitalForm", "Export", "GValueAdd", "HDD",           "HICP_Energy") dict %>%    filter(model_varname %in% vars) %>%    pull(database) #>  [1] NA         "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" #>  [7] "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" "edgar"

title: Example Workflow
text: now ready run model obtain "aggmod" object. quiet output, get information estimation. told local files used, namely file "example-workflow-data.rds", can found working directory "." vignette created. Next, obtain warning panel unbalanced, means “ragged edges” cause 20% data discarded limiting sample time periods available variables. Finally, estimation begins. order modules determined related , starting modules depend exogenous (unmodelled) variables gradually estimating modules order avoid reverse dependencies.
code: model <- run_model(specification = specification,                    dictionary = dict,                    inputdata_directory = ".",                    primary_source = "local",                    save_to_disk = NULL,                    present = FALSE,                    quiet = FALSE) #> Local files are used. #> The following files are opened and scanned for relevant data for the model. #> example-workflow-data.rds #> Note: If these include non-data files (with a likely different structure and hence likely errors), it is recommended to move all data files to a dedicated directory or to save them there using the 'save_to_disk' argument in the first place: #>  #> You can quiet this message with quiet = TRUE. #> Warning in load_or_download_variables(specification = module_order, dictionary #> = dictionary, : Unbalanced panel, will lose more than 20\% of data when making #> balanced #>  #> --- Estimation begins --- #> Estimating Import = FinConsExpHH + GCapitalForm  #> Estimating EmiCO2Combustion = HDD + HICP_Energy + GValueAdd  #> Constructing TOTS = GValueAdd + Import  #> Constructing StatDiscrep = TOTS - FinConsExpHH - FinConsExpGov - GCapitalForm - Export class(model) #> [1] "aggmod"

title: Example Workflow
text: Now, can look model results.

title: Example Workflow
text: different modules stored model$module_collection, tibble stores datasets, independent dependent variables, model arguments, model "isat" object. example, taking closer look estimated module carbon emissions combustion activities: find number heating degree days (HDD) gross value added (GValueAdd) significant, gets model selection dropped harmonised consumer price index energy. gross value added heating degree days positive coefficient meaning increase emissions, expect. diagnostic tests autocorrelation autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity pass.
code: # extract the isat model object co2module <- model$module_collection %>%    filter(dependent == "EmiCO2Combustion") %>%    pull(model) %>%    pluck(1) class(co2module) #> [1] "isat" # inspect the estimated equation print(co2module) #>  #> Date: Mon Jan 22 09:53:55 2024  #> Dependent var.: y  #> Method: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) #> Variance-Covariance: Ordinary  #> No. of observations (mean eq.): 88  #> Sample: 1 to 88  #>  #> SPECIFIC mean equation: #>  #>                     coef   std.error  t-stat   p-value     #> mconst        1.65723367  1.57041425  1.0553 0.2945119     #> trend        -0.00279700  0.00045517 -6.1449 3.051e-08 *** #> ln.HDD        0.09832576  0.02549129  3.8572 0.0002327 *** #> ln.GValueAdd  0.70874663  0.14185904  4.9961 3.434e-06 *** #> q_2          -0.24228972  0.03085694 -7.8520 1.692e-11 *** #> q_3          -0.27299057  0.05324977 -5.1266 2.049e-06 *** #> q_4          -0.05980636  0.01166827 -5.1256 2.057e-06 *** #> sis8          0.07357979  0.02039646  3.6075 0.0005401 *** #> sis13         0.07758571  0.01864915  4.1603 8.022e-05 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Diagnostics and fit: #>  #>                   Chi-sq df p-value   #> Ljung-Box AR(1)   3.1001  1 0.07829 . #> Ljung-Box ARCH(1) 1.8645  1 0.17210   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>                            #> SE of regression   0.03458 #> R-squared          0.97412 #> Log-lik.(n=88)   175.70269

title: Example Workflow
text: can use model forecast variables modules. works definition/identity modules endogenous modules. user can either provide future values exogenous variables (e.g. corresponding certain scenario assumptions) use automatic AR models forecast future values exogenous variables. specify paths exogenous regressors, output informs us AR(4) processes used project paths. function returns object class "aggmod.forecast", can also plotted.
code: forecast <- forecast_model(model = model,                            exog_predictions = NULL,                            plot.forecast = FALSE) #> No exogenous values provided. Model will forecast the exogenous values with an AR4 process (incl. Q dummies, IIS and SIS w 't.pval = 0.001'). #> Alternative is exog_fill_method = 'last'. class(forecast) #> [1] "aggmod.forecast" plot(forecast)

title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: example add new variable Dictionary:
code: # Add a new row to 'dict', which is an element of the aggregate.model package dict %>%    bind_rows(tibble(     model_varname = "IndProd", # this is free to choose but must be unique     full_name = "An index of Industrial Production",     database  = "eurostat",     variable_code = "PROD", # in this case use the bt_indicator information here     dataset_id = "sts_inpr_q",     var_col = "indic_bt", # here we specify what the column with the variables is called     freq = "q", # for quarterly data, 'm' would be monthly     geo = "AT",     unit = "I15", # for index of 2015 = 100     s_adj = "NSA", # not seasonally adjusted     nace_r2 = "B-D")) -> new_dict  # now use the new_dict in run_model

what: Some general remarks about the Dictionary
title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: dictionary central store information used us “translate” difficult data codes useful variable names - also central us tell Aggregate Model download. Let’s take look dictionary: words variables/columns dictionary: crucial columns nearly always needed/useful. : model_varname: Variable name model equations, must unique. full_name: Full name/description variable. Currently full use also columns: database: Name database. Internally implemented “eurostat” “edgar.” variable_code: Identifier variable applicable, e.g., Eurostat variable code. dataset_id: Identifier dataset variable available, e.g., Eurostat dataset code link file web. varied use : var_col: Name variable/column dataset. freq: Frequency variable dataset. “m” monthly, “q” quarterly. geo: ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code. unit: Eurostat unit variable measured, e.g., choose different measurements variable. s_adj: Eurostat seasonal adjustment . nace_r2: Eurostat identifier NACE Rev. 2 classification. ipcc_sector: EDGAR IPCC National Greenhouse Gas Inventories, see link. “TOTAL” official IPCC code internally interpreted use country totals. cpa2_1: Eurostat identifier Classification Products Activity (CPA). siec: Standard International Energy Product Classification, e.g., Eurostat.
code: dict %>% as_tibble %>% slice(1:10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 14 #>    model_varname full_name database variable_code dataset_id var_col freq  geo   #>    <chr>         <chr>     <chr>    <chr>         <chr>      <chr>   <chr> <chr> #>  1 TOTS          Total Su… NA       TOTS          NA         NA      NA    NA    #>  2 GDP           Gross do… eurostat B1GQ          namq_10_g… na_item q     AT    #>  3 GValueAdd     Value ad… eurostat B1G           namq_10_a… na_item q     AT    #>  4 Export        Exports … eurostat P6            namq_10_g… na_item q     AT    #>  5 Import        Imports … eurostat P7            namq_10_g… na_item q     AT    #>  6 GCapitalForm  Gross ca… eurostat P5G           namq_10_g… na_item q     AT    #>  7 FinConsExp    Final co… eurostat P3            namq_10_g… na_item q     AT    #>  8 FinConsExpGov Final co… eurostat P3_S13        namq_10_g… na_item q     AT    #>  9 FinConsExpHH  Househol… eurostat P31_S14_S15   namq_10_g… na_item q     AT    #> 10 StatDiscrep   Statisti… eurostat YA0           namq_10_g… na_item q     AT    #> # ℹ 6 more variables: unit <chr>, s_adj <chr>, nace_r2 <chr>, #> #   ipcc_sector <chr>, cpa2_1 <chr>, siec <lgl>

title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: Firstly, head Eurostat find variable like add. data viewer options Eurostat, recommend using “Data Explorer” . good link get started: Eurostat Data Viewer Data Navigation Tree

title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: Now let’s assume want add form Industrial Production dataset (Link). head back data tree select quarterly dataset Industrial Production (sts_inpr_q):  Now let’s take closer look data features typically top screen:  already gives us something crucial: dataset identifier, case sts_inpr_q. corresponds column dataset_id Dictionary dict. find even detailed features dataset, click big encircled + e.g. next “Time” “Unit Measure”. gives us ability play around bit define custom dataset specific needs:  really window need focus quite bit. First , note different dimensions data encapsulated square brackets [ ], like time, indicator_bt, s_adj, relevant marked yellow:  identify correct data, now need click different dimensions make note want use. available types vary depending Eurostat data, variables relevant Aggregate Model include: variable indicates specific variable name, like na_item indic_bt, depending Eurostat guidelines associated data collection method used. time geo: geography data belongs (see Glossary:Country codes - Statistics Explained (europa.eu) information format). unit: unit variable like €, tonnes, %, etc. (frequently also kind indices like I15 Index = 2015). corresponds unit column Dictionary dict. s_adj: Seasonal Adjustment, e.g. NSA refers “Seasonal Adjustment” Sometimes data consider can broken even , e.g. according sectors physical quantities (like different greenhouse gases). include example things like: nace_r2: column indicator indicates sector according Statistical classification economic activities European Community (NACE Revision 2) cp2_1: column indicator indicates Statistical classification products activity, 2.1 (CPA 2.1) siec: Standard International Energy Product Classification Based information , let’s say want add variable dataset sts_inpr_q: industrial production, spans NACE rev. 2 sectors sectors B D, Austria, using unit index set 2015 value seasonally adjusted.

title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: Given information, let’s try download first - using get_eurostat function {eurostat} package: Now let’s filter raw dataset data series need: looks quite good. can plot really quickly:
code: dat_raw <- get_eurostat(id = "sts_inpr_q") dat_raw #> # A tibble: 3,452,724 × 8 #>    freq  indic_bt nace_r2 s_adj unit  geo   TIME_PERIOD values #>    <chr> <chr>    <chr>   <chr> <chr> <chr> <date>       <dbl> #>  1 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1996-01-01    64.2 #>  2 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1996-04-01    85.6 #>  3 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1996-07-01    90.1 #>  4 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1996-10-01    87.1 #>  5 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1997-01-01    66.6 #>  6 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1997-04-01    82.1 #>  7 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1997-07-01    85.9 #>  8 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1997-10-01    82.2 #>  9 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1998-01-01    69.2 #> 10 Q     PROD     B       CA    I10   AT    1998-04-01    91.1 #> # ℹ 3,452,714 more rows dat_raw %>%    filter(indic_bt == "PROD", # for industrial production variable          nace_r2 == "B-D", # to select all NACE rev 2 sectors in B, C, and D          s_adj == "NSA", # to get the raw, non-adjusted data          unit == "I15", # to get the 2015 Index          geo == "AT" # to get only the Austrian data          ) -> dat_AT dat_AT #> # A tibble: 111 × 8 #>    freq  indic_bt nace_r2 s_adj unit  geo   TIME_PERIOD values #>    <chr> <chr>    <chr>   <chr> <chr> <chr> <date>       <dbl> #>  1 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1996-01-01    50.9 #>  2 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1996-04-01    51.9 #>  3 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1996-07-01    51.9 #>  4 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1996-10-01    56   #>  5 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1997-01-01    51.8 #>  6 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1997-04-01    55.7 #>  7 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1997-07-01    55.6 #>  8 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1997-10-01    60.9 #>  9 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1998-01-01    57.1 #> 10 Q     PROD     B-D     NSA   I15   AT    1998-04-01    60.4 #> # ℹ 101 more rows ggplot(dat_AT, aes(x = TIME_PERIOD, y = values, color = indic_bt)) +    geom_line(linewidth = 1) +       # add some styling   geom_hline(aes(yintercept = 0)) + # to get a line through 0   labs(title = "Industrial Production in Austria", x = NULL, y = "Industrial Production Index, 2015 = 100") +    theme_minimal(base_size = 15)+   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

what: Adding the variable to the dictionary
title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: Now know data looks like verified want add, can add dictionary. , consider column names dictionary . course checking documentation dict : Essentially, need add new variable dictionary simply adding new row. can e.g. rbind() bind_rows(). Depending variable consider, need fill many columns possible. example means: Now done successfully created new dictionary!!
code: dict %>% names #>  [1] "model_varname" "full_name"     "database"      "variable_code" #>  [5] "dataset_id"    "var_col"       "freq"          "geo"           #>  [9] "unit"          "s_adj"         "nace_r2"       "ipcc_sector"   #> [13] "cpa2_1"        "siec" ?dict dict %>%    bind_rows(tibble(     model_varname = "IndProd", # this is free to choose but must be unique     full_name = "An index of Industrial Production",     database  = "eurostat",     variable_code = "PROD", # in this case use the bt_indicator information here     dataset_id = "sts_inpr_q",     var_col = "indic_bt", # here we specify what the column with the variables is called     freq = "q", # for quarterly data, 'm' would be monthly     geo = "AT",     unit = "I15", # for index of 2015 = 100     s_adj = "NSA", # not seasonally adjusted     nace_r2 = "B-D")) -> new_dict new_dict %>%    as_tibble() %>%    tail #> # A tibble: 6 × 14 #>   model_varname  full_name database variable_code dataset_id var_col freq  geo   #>   <chr>          <chr>     <chr>    <chr>         <chr>      <chr>   <chr> <chr> #> 1 CDD            Cooling … eurostat CDD           nrg_chdd_m indic_… m     AT    #> 2 EmiCH4Livesto… Methane … edgar    NA            https://j… NA      m     AT    #> 3 EmiCO2Industry Carbon E… edgar    NA            https://j… NA      m     AT    #> 4 EmiCO2Combust… Carbon E… edgar    NA            https://j… NA      m     AT    #> 5 EmiN2OTotal    Nitrous … edgar    NA            https://j… NA      m     AT    #> 6 IndProd        An index… eurostat PROD          sts_inpr_q indic_… q     AT    #> # ℹ 6 more variables: unit <chr>, s_adj <chr>, nace_r2 <chr>, #> #   ipcc_sector <chr>, cpa2_1 <chr>, siec <lgl>

what: Quickly run a small model to check if it works:
title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: can now put test extremely small model. construct model CO[2] Emissions Industry function Gas Electricity Prices well new measure Industrial Production: \[ EmiCO2Industry = HICP_{Gas} + HICP_{Electricity} + IndProd \] put specification table alongside simple identity need moment current set-allow adding identities. specification set , now run model using new_dict constructed earlier. Let’s visualise model alongisde forecast:
code: specification <- dplyr::tibble(   type = c(     "n",     "d"   ),   dependent = c(     "EmiCO2Industry",     "TOTS"   ),   independent = c(     "HICP_Gas + HICP_Electricity + IndProd",     "GDP + Import"   ) ) specification #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   type  dependent      independent                           #>   <chr> <chr>          <chr>                                 #> 1 n     EmiCO2Industry HICP_Gas + HICP_Electricity + IndProd #> 2 d     TOTS           GDP + Import model <- run_model(specification = specification,                    dictionary = new_dict,                              present = FALSE,                    quiet = TRUE,                    constrain.to.minimum.sample = FALSE) mod_fcast <- forecast_model(model, plot.forecast = FALSE) #> No exogenous values provided. Model will forecast the exogenous values with an AR4 process (incl. Q dummies, IIS and SIS w 't.pval = 0.001'). #> Alternative is exog_fill_method = 'last'. plot(mod_fcast)

title: An Open-Source Macro-Econometric Model to forecast and study Climate Policies
text: calibrate model specification save tibble. column names structure specification table must follow basic structure . summarise , can print specification table: order run model, also need dictionary translates model variables EUROSTAT codes download process can automated. can either pass new dictionary model function, can use built dictionary aggregate.model::dict: last step specifying model create filter list determines country want estimate also unit need variable. , moment, quite tedious, improved future:
code: spec <- dplyr::tibble(   type = c(     "n",     "n",     "n",     "n",     "d",     "n",     "n",     "n",     "n"   ),   dependent = c(     "Import",     "FinConsExpHH",     "GCapitalForm",     "Emissions",     "GDP",     "GValueAddGov", # as in NAM, technical relationship     "GValueAddManuf", # more complicated in NAM, see 2.3.3 and 6.3.1     "GValueAddConstr" ,     "GValueAddWholesaletrade"   ),   independent = c(     "FinConsExpHH + GCapitalForm",     "",     "FinConsExpGov + FinConsExpHH",     "GDP + Export + GValueAddIndus",     "GValueAddGov + GValueAddAgri + GValueAddIndus + GValueAddConstr + GValueAddWholesaletrade + GValueAddInfocom + GValueAddFinance + GValueAddRealest + GValueAddResearch + GValueAddArts",     "FinConsExpGov", # as in NAM, technical relationship     "Export + LabCostManuf", # NAM uses 'export market indicator' not exports - unclear what this is, NAM uses unit labour cost in NOR manufacturing relative to the foreign price level - here is just total labour cost     "LabCostConstr + BuildingPermits", # in NAM some form of YFP2J = 0.3JBOL + 0.2JF P N + 0.3JO + 0.3JOIL. Unclear what this is. Using Building Permits instead     "Export + LabCostService"   )) fa <- list(geo = "AT", s_adj = "SCA", unit = "CLV05_MEUR") fb <- list(geo = "AT", s_adj = "SCA", unit = "CP_MEUR") fc <- list(geo = "AT", unit = "THS_T") fd <- list(geo = "AT", s_adj = "SCA") fe <- list(geo = "AT", s_adj = "SCA", unit = "I15") ff <- list(geo = "AT", s_adj = "SCA", unit = "I16")  filter_list <- list( "P7" = fa, "YA0" = fb, "P31_S14_S15" = fa, "P5G" = fa, "B1G" = fa, "P3_S13" = fa, "P6" = fa, "GHG" = fc, "B1GQ" = fa, "PSQM" = fe, "LM-LCI-TOT" = ff )

title: An Open-Source Macro-Econometric Model to forecast and study Climate Policies
text: Now ready run model run_model() function: first time run , data downloaded saved folder data/use/InputData.xlsx. next time run model, can save time just load data earlier run:
code: model_result <- run_model(   specification = spec,   filter_list = filter_list,   save_to_disk = "inst/extdata/InputData.xlsx",   download = TRUE,   trend = TRUE,   max.lag = 4,   saturation.tpval = 0.1/NROW(clean_data) ) #> Table namq_10_a10 cached at C:\Users\morit\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpmwe6Vh/eurostat/namq_10_a10_date_code_FF.rds #> Table namq_10_gdp cached at C:\Users\morit\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpmwe6Vh/eurostat/namq_10_gdp_date_code_FF.rds #> Table env_ac_aigg_q cached at C:\Users\morit\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpmwe6Vh/eurostat/env_ac_aigg_q_date_code_FF.rds #> Table ei_lmlc_q cached at C:\Users\morit\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpmwe6Vh/eurostat/ei_lmlc_q_date_code_FF.rds #> Table sts_cobp_q cached at C:\Users\morit\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpmwe6Vh/eurostat/sts_cobp_q_date_code_FF.rds #> Warning in load_or_download_variables(specification = #> module_order_eurostatvars, : Unbalanced panel, will lose more than 20\% of data #> when making balanced #>  #> --- Estimation begins --- #> Estimating GValueAddGov = FinConsExpGov  #> Estimating GValueAddManuf = Export + LabCostManuf  #> Estimating GValueAddConstr = LabCostConstr + BuildingPermits  #> Estimating GValueAddWholesaletrade = Export + LabCostService  #> Estimating FinConsExpHH =   #> Constructing GDP = GValueAddGov + GValueAddAgri + GValueAddIndus + GValueAddConstr + GValueAddWholesaletrade + GValueAddInfocom + GValueAddFinance + GValueAddRealest + GValueAddResearch + GValueAddArts  #> Estimating GCapitalForm = FinConsExpGov + FinConsExpHH  #> Estimating Emissions = GDP + Export + GValueAddIndus  #> Estimating Import = FinConsExpHH + GCapitalForm model_result <- run_model(   specification = spec,   filter_list = filter_list,   download = FALSE,   inputdata_directory = "inst/extdata",   trend = TRUE,   max.lag = 4,   saturation.tpval = 0.1/NROW(clean_data) )

title: An Open-Source Macro-Econometric Model to forecast and study Climate Policies
text: Now run model, can forecast model (using AR process exogenous values 10 time periods): done, can plot forecast:
code: model_forecast <- forecast_model(model_result, n.ahead = 10, exog_fill_method = "AR", plot.forecast = FALSE) #> No exogenous values provided. Model will forecast the exogenous values with an AR4 process (incl. Q dummies, IIS and SIS w 't.pval = 0.001'). #> Alternative is exog_fill_method = 'last'. plot(model_forecast, order.as.run = TRUE) #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_line()`).

title: Add the estimated fitted values back to the original — add_to_original_data
code: sample_data <- dplyr::tibble(   time = rep(seq.Date(     from = as.Date("2000-01-01"),     to = as.Date("2000-12-31"), by = 1   ), each = 2),   na_item = rep(c("yvar", "xvar"), 366), values = rnorm(366 * 2, mean = 100) ) sample_data_clean <- aggregate.model:::clean_data(sample_data, max.ar = 4, max.dl = 4) estimation <- aggregate.model:::estimate_module(sample_data_clean, "yvar", "xvar") aggregate.model:::add_to_original_data(   sample_data_clean, estimation$best_model,   dep_var_basename = "yvar") #> # A tibble: 366 × 30 #>    index time       trend  yvar  xvar ln.yvar ln.xvar D.ln.yvar D.ln.xvar #>    <int> <date>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1     1 2000-01-01     1  98.6 100.     4.59    4.61  NA       NA        #>  2     2 2000-01-02     2  97.6 100.     4.58    4.61  -0.0106  -0.00261  #>  3     3 2000-01-03     3 101.  101.     4.61    4.62   0.0309   0.0115   #>  4     4 2000-01-04     4  98.2  99.8    4.59    4.60  -0.0246  -0.0139   #>  5     5 2000-01-05     5  99.8  99.7    4.60    4.60   0.0159  -0.000355 #>  6     6 2000-01-06     6  99.4 101.     4.60    4.61  -0.00311  0.00910  #>  7     7 2000-01-07     7 102.   98.4    4.63    4.59   0.0260  -0.0227   #>  8     8 2000-01-08     8 101.   98.1    4.61    4.59  -0.0153  -0.00236  #>  9     9 2000-01-09     9  99.5  99.9    4.60    4.60  -0.0103   0.0183   #> 10    10 2000-01-10    10 101.   99.1    4.61    4.60   0.0106  -0.00866  #> # ℹ 356 more rows #> # ℹ 21 more variables: L1.D.ln.yvar <dbl>, L1.D.ln.xvar <dbl>, #> #   L1.ln.yvar <dbl>, L1.ln.xvar <dbl>, L2.D.ln.yvar <dbl>, L2.D.ln.xvar <dbl>, #> #   L2.ln.yvar <dbl>, L2.ln.xvar <dbl>, L3.D.ln.yvar <dbl>, L3.D.ln.xvar <dbl>, #> #   L3.ln.yvar <dbl>, L3.ln.xvar <dbl>, L4.D.ln.yvar <dbl>, L4.D.ln.xvar <dbl>, #> #   L4.ln.yvar <dbl>, L4.ln.xvar <dbl>, q_2 <int>, q_3 <int>, q_4 <int>, #> #   yvar.hat <dbl>, yvar.level.hat <dbl>

Default TRUE. selection.tpval Numeric. target p-value model selection methods (.e. general--specific modelling, see 'getsm' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01.

Column names must : 'type', 'dependent', 'independent'. column 'type' must contain row character either 'd' (Identity) 'n' (Definition - .e. estimated). column 'dependent' must contain LHS (Y variables) column named 'independent' containing RHS (x variables separated + -). dictionary tibble data.frame storing Eurostat variable code column 'eurostat_code' model variable name 'model_varname'. download == TRUE dictionary also requires column named 'dataset_id' stores Eurostat dataset id. NULL, default dictionary used. inputdata_directory path .rds input files data stored. Can NULL download == TRUE. primary_source string. Determines whether "download" "local" data loading takes precedence. save_to_disk path directory final dataset saved, including file name ending. saved NULL. present logical value whether final aggregate model output presented . NOTE: implemented yet. quiet Logical default = FALSE. messages displayed? messages intended give information estimation data retrieval process. use_logs decide whether log variables. Must one "", "y", "x". Default "". trend Logical. trend added? Default TRUE. ardl_or_ecm Either 'ardl' 'ecm' determine whether estimate model Autoregressive Distributed Lag Function (ardl) Equilibrium Correction Model (ecm). max.ar Integer. maximum number lags use AR terms. well independent variables. max.dl Integer. maximum number lags use independent variables (distributed lags). saturation Carry Indicator Saturation using 'isat' function 'gets' package. Needes character vector string. Default 'c("IIS","SIS")' carry Impulse Indicator Saturation Step Indicator Saturation. possible values 'NULL' disable 'TIS' Trend Indicator Saturation. disabled, estimation carried using 'arx' function 'gets' package. saturation.tpval target p-value saturation methods (e.g. SIS IIS, see 'isat' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. max.block.size Integer. Maximum size block variables selected , default = 20. gets_selection Logical. Whether general--specific selection using 'getsm' function 'gets' package done final saturation model. Default TRUE. selection.tpval Numeric. target p-value model selection methods (.e. general--specific modelling, see 'getsm' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. constrain..minimum.sample Logical. data series constrained minimum data series? Default TRUE.

what: Translate model variable names to Eurostat codes — translate_variables
title: Translate model variable names to Eurostat codes — translate_variables
text: Takes specification translates model variable names Eurostat codes. Also adds Eurostat dataset identifier variable extracted.

title: Translate model variable names to Eurostat codes — translate_variables
code: translate_variables(specification, dictionary = NULL)

title: Translate model variable names to Eurostat codes — translate_variables
text: specification tibble data.frame one column named 'dependent' contains LHS (Y) variables one column named 'independent' contains RHS (x) variables, separated + - . Column 'type' specify whether dependent variable endogenous modelling ("n") endogenous accounting definition ("d"). dictionary tibble data.frame storing model variable names column named 'model_varname' corresponding Eurostat variable code 'eurostat_code'. NULL, default dictionary used.

title: Translate model variable names to Eurostat codes — translate_variables
text: Returns tibble data.frame input specification two added columns model variable name (model_varname) dataset identifier (dataset_id).
